title: European stock markets slide on China plunge
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Jul 27, 2015, 12:31 BST - UK Markets close in 3 hrs 59 mins European stock markets slide on China plunge By Roland Jackson | AFP – 14 minutes ago View Photo 

European stock markets sank on Monday as investors reacted to the biggest one-day plunge in Chinese equities in more than eight years. 
Markets meanwhile awaited this week's US Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting for a handle on its plans for interest rates. 
Nearing midday deals, London's benchmark FTSE 100 index of major blue-chip companies dropped 0.15 percent to 6,569.70 points. 
Frankfurt's DAX 30 shed 1.19 percent to 11,212 points and the CAC 40 in Paris lost 1.37 percent to 4,987.90 compared with Friday's close. 
"The collapse in the Chinese market is worrying for two reasons: it pulls the other markets lower due to short-term sentiment, but more importantly it sends a message that the second-largest economy in the world is starting to stall," IG (LSE: IGG.L - news ) analyst David Madden told AFP. 
"The Chinese authorities have been doing their utmost to prop up the market but to no avail, and now after a series of sharp declines traders know the party is over." 
- Worst yet to come? - 
"Global (Shenzhen: 300465.SZ - news ) equity markets have not fully factored in the Chinese meltdown, and the worst is yet to come as the Asian power house slows down," said Madden. 
Chinese markets suffered a second straight day of selling on increasing fears about the state of the mainland economy after a gauge of manufacturing activity fell in July to its lowest level in 15 months. 
And on Monday figures showed profits at the country's industrial firms slipped 0.3 percent year-on-year in June. 
Shanghai shares plunged 8.48 percent despite government efforts to prop up the market. The decline was its biggest single-day drop since February 2007, according to Bloomberg News. 
"China is the world?s second biggest economy and is plumbed into the world?s capital markets, so when there is trouble there you can expect some impact abroad," agreed analyst Laith Khalaf at brokerage Hargreaves Lansdown (LSE: HL.L - news ) . 
Elsewhere in Asia, Hong Kong tanked 3.09 percent, Tokyo declined 0.95 percent and Seoul gave up 0.35 percent, but Sydney added 0.43 percent. 
"The variety of reasons why this latest Chinese plunge has had such an effect on the markets captures the reasons why China itself is such a huge, and worrying, figure in the macro-economic landscape," added Spreadex analyst Connor Campbell. 
- Dollar week before Fed - 
The dollar meanwhile remained weak after a disappointing read on the US housing market, as investors await the US Federal Reserve's next monetary policy decision due Wednesday. 
In foreign exchange activity in London on Monday, the European single currency rose to $1.1067 from $1.0977 late in New York on Friday. 
While the Fed is not expected to raise rates this week, dealers are hoping for some forward guidance, with most analysts tipping a hike in either September or December. 
Back in London on Monday, British publisher Pearson (Xetra: 858266 - news ) topped the fallers after revealing Saturday (Shenzhen: 002291.SZ - news ) that it was in talks to sell its 50-percent share in The Economist Group. 
The announcement comes just two days after Pearson agreed to sell the Financial Times to Japanese media group Nikkei for £844 million ($1.3 billion, 1.2 billion euros), saying that it wanted to focus solely on the education publishing sector which accounts for most of its business. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) tumbled 3.53 percent to 1,176 pence in midday London trade. 
On the upside, household goods firm Reckitt Benckiser (Xetra: A0M1W6 - news ) rose as rising revenues and a brighter outlook eclipsed news of sliding first-half net profit. 
Reckitt, which produces Durex condoms, household cleaner Cillit Bang, and Nurofen pain relief tablets, saw its share price gain 2.81 percent to 6,074 pence.
